review_title: TRCP is a solid conservation organization and employer
pros:
Great mission and one of only a few NGOs that focus almost exclusively on natural resources policy and legislation. Very effective organization at influencing the development, passage, and implementation of policy and legislation. Really like the partner/coalition model - strength in numbers and diversity helps with effectiveness. 

Reasonable pay for most staff and good benefits for an NGO of its size. A flexible work schedule and ample vacation time plus opportunities to get paid to recreate in the outdoors while doing ones job! Smart and dedicated staff for the most part and good collegial environment.
cons:
Often times the organization is spread thin with too many priorities and not enough capacity to adequately address all of them. 

While the partner model is great, it can sometimes be challenging to mange the breadth of organizations, personalities and political leanings of different organizations involved and it takes a lot of staff time to do so. 

Training opportunities for individual growth is seriously lacking for most staff. Those supervising other staff could use supervisory and leadership training - some seemingly have never supervised before nor have been trained to do so effectively. 

Regarding growth of staff within the organization, there are zero to very limited opportunities to move up in the organizational chart - i.e., no clear career path opportunities, some of which is indeed driven by the size of the organization and it's focused mission.

review_title: There Is Little to No Diversity Here
pros: The pay and benefits are decent, but the working environment isn’t worth it.
cons: Looking for a workplace that resembles our uniqueness as a country? This isn’t it! A very non-supportive, toxic, and non-inclusive working environment. The Chiefs lead with a bully management style - they micromanage, they intimidate you and they don’t care about boundaries. This isn’t a human-centered organization. They don’t care about you; especially if you’re disabled, a BIPOC or LGBQT+
